text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
This IRM section was revised to incorporate Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0418-0006, Initial Conference for Liability, Penalty Appeals and Innocent Spouse Cases.

Conference for Liability, Penalty Appeals and Innocent Spouse Cases. Changed throughout this IRM section the term “Appeals hearing officer” to the term Appeals Technical Employee or (ATE). Added new IRM
, Program Scope and Objectives, and related sections containing internal control information required by IRM

, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process. As a result, other IRM sections were renumbered. Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Website addresses, legal and IRM references have been reviewed and updated. References to the following consent forms were removed:
editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Website addresses, legal references, IRM references have been reviewed and updated.

Incorporated Servicewide Memorandum from Deputy Commissioner for Services and Enforcement, Revision of Policy for Use of Fax in Taxpayer Submissions, dated November 19, 2015.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 8.21.3, Appeals Technical Employees Statute Responsibility, dated August 28, 2014 and incorporates Internal Guidance AP-08-0418-0006, Initial Conference Procedures for Liability, Penalty Appeals and Innocent Spouse Cases. Incorporated Servicewide Memorandum from Deputy Commissioner for Services and Enforcement, Revision of Policy for Use of Fax in Taxpayer Submissions, dated November 19, 2015.

) Purpose - This IRM section provides procedures and guidance to Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs) for protecting assessment statutes and for preparing and processing consents on all cases assigned. This IRM follows guidelines established in IRM
, Extension of Assessment Statute of Limitations By Consent, when preparing consent forms. (
) Audience - Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs). (
) Policy Owner - Appeals Policy is under Director, Case and Operations (
) Program Owner - Appeals Policy is the program office responsible for technical and procedural guidance to the Appeals organization. (

) Contact Information - Appeals employees should follow established on How to Contact an Analyst. Other employees should contact the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog information page for this (

) This IRM section provides procedures for extending the assessment statute limitations by consent agreement. It serves as a supplemental guidance for Appeals Technical employees and follows the established procedures in IRM
, Statute of Limitations, Extension of Assessment Statute of Limitations by Consent, which is the primary guidance for all IRS (
) Appeals is the Internal Revenue Service’s dispute resolution forum. (

) Appeals accomplishes its mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases, holding conferences, and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employee act in accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. IRC
). See also Pub
, Taxpayer Bill of Rights. (

) The Director, Case and Operations Support (COS) is the executive for designing, developing, delivering, and monitoring short and long range administration policies, programs, strategies, and objectives for the Appeals organization. (
) The Director, Policy, is responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to Appeals employees, establishing and maintaining policies and standard procedures for Appeals work streams. (
) The Policy Analyst shown on the Product Catalog page as the originator is assigned author of this IRM. (
) Planning, Quality, and Analysis (PQA) provide trends and data analyses detailed summary reports for Appeals. Internal Revenue Manual

The Director, Case and Operations Support (COS) is the executive for designing, developing, delivering, and monitoring short and long range administration policies, programs, strategies, and objectives for the organization. The Director, Policy, is responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to Appeals employees, establishing and maintaining policies standard procedures for Appeals work streams. 8.21 Appeals Statute Responsibility

This IRM is the primary source of guidance on this program. The following table lists additional sources of guidance. Together, this material forms the operating rules and responsibilities for this program.

Source Title Guidance On IRM 25.6.22 Statute of Preparing and Limitations, securing extensions Extension of of the period of time Assessment Statute for assessment. of Limitations by Consent IRC 6501(c)(4) Extension of time to Extension by Assess Tax agreement. IRC 6901(d) Extension of time to Extension by assess tax against a agreement. transferee
ATEs are responsible for protecting assessment statutes and monitoring collec- tion statutes on all cases assigned to them. Their responsibilities are to:

Monitor statutes on non-docketed cases they send to Counsel. Verify suspended statutes to ensure they ﬁt the suspension criteria. Ensure the accurate statute is reﬂected on Appeals Centralized System (ACDS). When an ACDS statute update, modiﬁcation or change
Technical Employees Statute Responsibility 8.21.3
is needed, use the Statute Validation Tracking System (SVS) in ACDS update, modify or change the statute critical data ﬁeld.

) Statute Code Note: Generally, this procedure won’t apply to collection statute expiration dates (CSEDs). See IRM
, Statute Responsibility in CDP, for guidance. (

) If an ATE is out of the office, absent a factor outside the employee’s control, such as an emergency, the employee must notify the Appeals Team (ATM) of any action needed to protect a short statute in his/her absence. (
) Appeals will not accept a proposed deﬁciency case if the number of days remaining on the Assessment Statute Expiration Date (ASED) for a new receipt is less than
days, with exceptions for estate tax cases and excise tax cases as shown below: a. Appeals will not accept an estate tax case for assessment if less than
days remain on the ASED. See also IRM
b. Appeals will not accept a case for an IRC

Appeals can return a case to Compliance for consideration if the taxpayer raises a new issue, new argument, or provides information not previously con- sidered by Compliance during the appeals process providing there are at least 210 days remaining on the ASED at the time the case is received by Compli- ance. 180 days must remain on the ASED for Appeals to accept the case from Compliance after their consideration of the new issue, new argument or

calendar days of receipt of a newly assigned and/or transferred (i.e., date of CR/NR), the ATE will complete the statute veriﬁcation. The statute veriﬁcation time frame shall not be extended beyond
days. For TEFRA key cases, this guidance shall extend the statute veriﬁcation time frame provided in IRM
, Appeals Technical Employees (ATE) Statute Responsibility for TEFRA Key Cases, to
calendar days for ﬁeld ATEs only. The ﬁve (

) workday time frame for validation by the TEFRA ATE, done prior to assignment of the case to a ﬁeld ATE, shall remain in effect. The ATE must review the ﬁle to validate that all statute dates are correctly shown on ACDS. This includes the veriﬁcation of the original statute, as well as vali- dation of all extensions. Verifying the statute date in ACDS signiﬁes that the ATE has reviewed the available source documents, IDRS, and completed any necessary research. If the ATE determines that the statute date reﬂected on ACDS is not correct and changes are necessary, the ATE must update the
Appeals Statute Responsibility
statute critical data ﬁelds using the Statute Validation System (SVS). See

) Because many cases are transferred due to workload considerations, addi- tional consideration is necessary with respect to special consents. If the preliminary review indicates one or more statutes are extended using a consent Form
-A, Special Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Tax, Form
-O, Special Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Tax able to Partnership Items, or mail Form
-U, Change of IRS Address to Submit Notice of Termination of Special Consent to Extend the Time to Tax, to the taxpayer. See also IRM

) An entry in the Case Activity Record (CAR) is automatically made by the when a statute validation has been completed. A sub-action code entry of with the date of validation, is added to the CAR for every workunit in the The “VA” entry on the CAR will indicate that the ATE has veriﬁed the statute date on ACDS. Any further explanations or unusual circumstances should be documented in the CAR. (

) If the statute date shown on ACDS is incorrect, the ATE will use the “Valida- tions” link at the bottom of the Case Summary Card screen to access the menu. Select ATE-Statute from the list to proceed to the SVS screen and make the necessary updates to the statute date or statute code. (
) If assigned a docketed case, the ATE must review the following documents verify that the non-petitioning spouse (NPS) and all non-petitioned years are assessed: a. Form
, Appeals Closing Record, with a noted DLN and
C b. TXMOD, IMFOL, or BMFOL showing the assessment. (

) ATEs should request a transcript every six months on any tax period with an ACDS statute code “SUB” to determine if a return was ﬁled by the taxpayer. The ﬁling of a return starts the running of a live statute from the date the is received. See also IRM
, Substitute for Return (SFR). (

) ATEs are responsible for monitoring their time sheets and monthly statute to ensure all statute updates, modiﬁcations and changes are correctly on ACDS and are noted correctly in the Validation Tracking Log (VTL). Note: See IRM
, Receipt of New Assignment by an Appeals Technical Employee (ATE), for additional information. (

) All changes to the statute critical data ﬁelds (tax period, statute date, and statute code) may be made from the SVS screen. Once the changes are entered and the validation is submitted, the return is updated on ACDS and log entry is made in the Validation Tracking Log.
If assigned a docketed case, the ATE must review the following documents to verify that the non-petitioning spouse (NPS) and all non-petitioned years (NPY)

ATEs should request a transcript every six months on any tax period with an ACDS statute code “SUB” to determine if a return was ﬁled by the taxpayer. The ﬁling of a return starts the running of a live statute from the date the return is received. See also IRM 25.6.1.9.4.5, Substitute for Return (SFR).
Note: See IRM 8.2.1.4, Receipt of New Assignment by an Appeals Technical Employee (ATE), for additional information.

All changes to the statute critical data ﬁelds (tax period, statute date, and statute code) may be made from the SVS screen. Once the changes are entered and the validation is submitted, the return is updated on ACDS and a log entry is made in the Validation Tracking Log.

statute code) may be made from the SVS screen. Once the changes are entered and the validation is submitted, the return is updated on ACDS and a log entry is made in the Validation Tracking Log. If the tax period also requires an update to the AIMS database or any other system as a result of the updated statute critical data ﬁeld, submit a request to the Processing Team Manager (PTM) for the AIMS update via the SVS. Select the appropriate office and PTM from the drop
down list in the SVS system to submit the request to the Appeals Processing Employee Automated System (PEAS) inbox.

page a. If you don’t receive conﬁrmation of the AIMS update within ﬁve (
) business days, contact the PTM who received the original update for resolution. (
) If there’s doubt as to the correct statute date, enter the earliest date deter- mined. Immediately correct ACDS using SVS, if a change is required. (
) Generate a monthly
-day Statute Report from ACDS on your inventory of cases and do the following: a. Annotate the list by the
th business day of the month with appropriate status/actions to be taken and submit it to the ATM; and b. Include the date consents were solicited, received and updated on ACDS. (
) Notify your ATM of any previously submitted cases appearing on the list with
days or less remaining on the statutory period. In these instances, the will follow-up with the PTM to conﬁrm the case will timely close. (
) Notify your ATM if any case appears on the
-day Statute Report that was submitted for closing within the past
days. (

) Determine whether a statute requires protection to ensure the statutory for assessment doesn’t expire. The statute is protected by the following actions: a. Assessing the appropriate deﬁciency or overassessment on an agreed case. b. Securing a consent to extend the statute of limitations. c. Issuing a Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency (SND). (
) Consider seeking advice from Counsel when unusual or complex consent and/or statute questions arise. (
) Once you determine that a consent is needed, every effort should be made obtain at least a six-month extension of the statutory period. (
) If the taxpayer requests an extension period that is shorter than needed to complete the appeal and other administrative actions, Appeals is not to agree to such period. (
) Both the taxpayer and Appeals have the right to determine what they will to in the consent. (

) Generally cases are received with ample time left on the statute to resolve issues and close the case. Initiate statute protection when it is determined resolution of the case may not occur within the speciﬁed time frame. (
) The protection can be initiated at any time; however, when there are at least
days left on the statute and you determine that no settlement will be reached, you must protect the statute by securing a consent or initiating preparation of a SND. (
) Below are time-frames to follow for protecting statutes: Internal Revenue Manual

Below are time-frames to follow for protecting statutes:

) Statute dates on estate tax cases can’t be extended by consent under any cir- cumstance, so the time to consider and resolve an estate tax case may be very limited. Appeals won’t accept an estate tax case if less than
days remain on the ASED. (
) You must consult with the ATM on any estate tax case that has only
days remaining on the statute. Written permission from your ATM is required to keep a case beyond the

-day guideline. Under these guidelines, you might need to prepare a SND even though Appeals consideration is just getting underway. Granting permission doesn’t address the performance aspects of the employ- ee’s critical elements. (

) Follow the time frames below. However, if a settlement is imminent, discuss with your ATM whether to allow more time in order to proceed to preparing a settlement computation, rather than preparing a SND. a. Initiate preparation of the SND when no settlement is reached and only
Initiate preparation of the SND when no settlement is reached and only 90 days remain on the statute.

, Separate Notiﬁcation of Each Spouse. If you can verify that both spouses live at the same address, it’s acceptable to send one consent form and Letter

) To verify that both spouses live at the same address, you must verify (either phone or in person) during the ﬁrst contact that the last known mailing is still correct for each spouse. a. One consent form signed by both spouses or two consent forms signed by each spouse is sufficient veriﬁcation that both spouses received of their rights. b. If you receive a consent form with only one spouse’s signature, it can’t be determined with certainty that the other spouse received the notice of their rights. In this case, you must contact the non-signing spouse to determine why there was only one signature on the consent form. Obtain a correct address, and send a separate consent form and Letter
(with Publication
) to the spouse who didn’t sign the consent form. c. If you can’t verify that both spouses live at the same address, you must send the consent form and Letter
(with Publication
) to each individual ﬁling a joint return. (

) When Appeals receives a valid signed consent from the taxpayer or representative, the ATE (assigned to the case) or other delegated individual will execute the consent by signing and dating the consent. Update the on ACDS using the Statute Validation menu. See IRM

for proce- dures for updating statutes in ACDS. Select the ACDS CARATS action and sub-action code CO-CR at the time the valid signed consent is received from the taxpayer or authorized representative. (

, and others) of amount; • Taxpayer closing agreements involving any amount of tax; and • Consents to extend the time to assess tax (Forms

) Consents pertaining to returns (including dummy returns where the original return wasn’t available) under the control and jurisdiction of Appeals are prepared, executed, and accepted in duplicate. Attach the original executed consent to the reverse side of the front page of the latest year’s return. copies of the executed consent to the reverse side of the front page of the return of the other years covered in the consent. Note: When the original executed consent must be forwarded to another office be affixed to the return, retain a copy of the consent for use in the event original is not received by the addressee. (

) If required consents aren’t obtainable or the consents aren’t acceptable, Appeals issues a SND for taxes and/or penalties subject to a petition to the United States Tax Court and takes necessary action(s) to protect the ment’s interests for all other taxes. See IRM
, Guidelines for Cases Special Issues, for information about cases involving criminal prosecution. (
) Never alter the extension date on the consent form. Prepare new consents, the date is in error or needs to be changed. (

) When prepayment credits are overstated, determine whether a different statutory period of limitation applies to such credits and take action to the Government’s interest. When claimed prepayment credits are and expiration of the statutory period of limitation is imminent, invite the taxpayer, in writing, to ﬁle a claim for refund to protect his or her interests. (
) Scrutinize the signed consent form for any unauthorized alterations, and your ATM of such unauthorized alterations. (
) Follow all of the above procedures each time a consent is solicited. (

Appeals Statute (
) Appeals will accept pre-assessed IRC
cases with at least
days remaining on the statute. (
) Cases with less than
days remaining on the statute will be returned to Compliance for assessment. (

) ATEs are responsible for ensuring that the Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency (SND) issued by Appeals, as well as the Final Partnership Administrative justment (FPAA) on TEFRA key cases, is timely prepared and issued. The decision to issue a SND must be approved by the ATM. (
) To ensure the statute is protected, a case must have at least
days remaining on the statute before it’s submitted for preparation of a SND. (
) If a SND is returned undeliverable, APS notiﬁes the ATE assigned to the The ATE immediately reviews the ﬁle to ensure that the proper address used in the notice. (
) If the last known address was used in the notice, the ATE initials, dates immediately returns the notice to APS, and no further action is needed. (
) If the last known address was not used in the notice and the ATE that the notice must be re-mailed or re-issued, the ATE will advise APS of actions to take. (
) When a SND is forwarded to Counsel for review, statute control remains with the ATE assigned the case even though Counsel has the its possession and was advised of the short statute. (

) On an annual basis, all ATEs and their ATMs conduct a physical inventory statute veriﬁcation of all returns in their inventory by comparing an listing generated from ACDS against their actual inventory. Annotations are made to the listing and any changes that the ATE can’t make are returned APS for update of ACDS. See IRM
, Appeals Inventory Validation Process. (
) Ensure that the procedural dates concerning jeopardy and termination ments are met, as provided in IRM
, Jeopardy and Termination Assessments Cases. (
) Ensure there are at least
days remaining on the statute when a case is submitted to the ATM for review and closing. See IRM
for rules concerning Estate Tax cases where settlement discussions break after ATM permission is granted to keep the case open beyond the
day date. (

) Written permission from the ATM is required to keep a case beyond the day guideline. Granting permission doesn’t address the performance of the employee’s Critical Elements. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
